name: David Miller
life_stage: Mid-career executive at a scaling series C startup.
relevant_history: Managed migration from HubSpot to Salesforce; built internal compliance tool for data masking.
emotional_baseline: Measured, focused on risk mitigation and ROI.
in_their_voice: If the AI touches PII without a BAA, it doesn't matter how fast it is; we can't use it.

name: Sarah Jenkins
life_stage: Experienced leader in highly regulated finance sector.
relevant_history: Oversees all third-party vendor assessments; previously rejected two AI tools for lack of SOC2.
emotional_baseline: Direct, values transparency and security documentation.
in_their_voice: Our current tool stack is a digital Rolodex; we need behavioral intelligence that doesn't leak data.

name: Elena Rodriguez
life_stage: Strategic lead for a mid-sized pharmaceutical consulting firm.
relevant_history: Implemented strict SOPs for data governance after a minor breach last year.
emotional_baseline: Alert, prioritizes compliance over feature richness.
in_their_voice: I'll pay a premium for a tool that lives in our VPC and keeps our auditors happy.

name: Michael Chen
occupation: Head of Data Privacy, Health Insurance
life_stage: Ensuring enterprise-wide HIPAA compliance across all new software.
relevant_history: Background in cybersecurity; skeptical of 'all-in-one' platforms that hide their architecture.
in_their_voice: Don't tell me it's 'secure'—show me the encryption keys and the on-prem deployment options.

name: Karen Thompson
life_stage: Scaling an agency that handles sensitive government contracts.
relevant_history: Lost a bid because their current qualitative tools didn't meet the required security tier.
emotional_baseline: Business-oriented, seeking a competitive edge through security.
in_their_voice: We need to understand our customers without putting their PII at risk in a public cloud.

name: Robert Vance
life_stage: Senior executive managing legacy systems and modernizing tool stacks.
relevant_history: Spent 20 years in enterprise IT; seen many AI hype cycles come and go.
emotional_baseline: Pragmatic, values stability and integration with existing CRMs.
in_their_voice: If it doesn't plug into our Salesforce instance seamlessly, it's just another silo.

name: Linda Wu
life_stage: Late-career lawyer specializing in healthcare data regulation.
relevant_history: Drafts BAAs and data processing agreements; knows exactly what compliance looks like.
in_their_voice: I'm looking for the 'No'—the point where your data security fails under scrutiny.

name: Susan Graves
life_stage: Ensures all research protocols meet international standards.
relevant_history: Audited dozens of research tools; values on-premise solutions.
in_their_voice: Compliance isn't a feature; it's the foundation of everything we do.

name: James O'Connor
life_stage: Advising startups on scaling their financial and data infrastructure.
relevant_history: Managed budget for multi-million dollar CRM implementations; knows the hidden costs of SaaS.
in_their_voice: Pick a niche and go deep—don't try to be Salesforce if you're not.

name: Patricia Lee
life_stage: Near retirement, ensuring a legacy of robust data standards.
relevant_history: Built the compliance department from scratch over 15 years.
emotional_baseline: Stern but fair, values proven results over flashy demos.
in_their_voice: We handle the most sensitive data there is; your tool needs to be a fortress.

name: Charles Foster
life_stage: Veteran ops leader managing massive customer datasets.
relevant_history: Saw the transition from paper records to cloud; deeply understands data vulnerability.
in_their_voice: Efficiency is great, but security is non-negotiable in this industry.

name: Thomas Wright
life_stage: Managing the risk profile of a Fortune 500 insurance company.
relevant_history: Oversees all software procurement through a risk-first lens.
emotional_baseline: Quietly skeptical, looks for edge cases.
in_their_voice: AI is a risk until proven otherwise—show me how you handle the edge cases of PII.

name: Barbara King
life_stage: High-level advisor to government health agencies.
relevant_history: Works with ultra-sensitive patient datasets; needs absolute privacy guarantees.
emotional_baseline: Intellectual, values privacy as a human right.
in_their_voice: Our clients won't even look at your tool if it's not hosted in a certified cloud.

name: Nancy Hall
life_stage: Serving on multiple corporate boards; advising on tech strategy.
relevant_history: Decades of financial oversight; seen the impact of data breaches on market cap.
emotional_baseline: Authoritative, looks at the big picture.
in_their_voice: A tool that solves a specific problem securely is worth ten times an 'all-in-one' risk.

name: Gary Scott
life_stage: The final gatekeeper for all software used in the bank.
relevant_history: Conducts deep-dive audits on every vendor; knows every trick in the book.
in_their_voice: I'm not here for the features; I'm here for the audit logs and the encryption.

name: Chloe Adams
life_stage: Early career, eager to prove value but buried in transcription.
relevant_history: Tried several transcription apps, but still spends hours cleaning up the text.
emotional_baseline: Stressed, looking for a way to breathe.
in_their_voice: I spend 80% of my time transcribing and only 20% actually thinking about the findings.

name: Jason Rivera
life_stage: Solopreneur building a client base; needs to deliver high quality fast.
relevant_history: Uses Rev and Otter.ai but finds the synthesis lacking; manual thematic coding is killing his margin.
in_their_voice: I need a tool that doesn't just transcribe but actually helps me find the patterns across interviews.

name: Mark Stevens
life_stage: Mid-level consultant at a mid-sized firm; handles multiple projects at once.
relevant_history: Manages teams of researchers; frustrated by the lack of consistency in manual analysis.
in_their_voice: We need to go from 'interview' to 'insight' in days, not weeks.

name: Liz Scimitar
life_stage: Independent consultant specializing in customer discovery and pain-point identification.
relevant_history: Uses ChatGPT for summaries but finds it prompt-dependent; needs cross-role comparison.
emotional_baseline: Expert, seeking structure for her specialized workflow.
in_their_voice: I need to see how executives vs. operators describe the same problem without manual tagging.

name: Rachel Green
life_stage: Leading a small team to rapidly test new product concepts.
relevant_history: Tried NVivo but found it too clunky for 'agile' research; needs something faster.
emotional_baseline: Energetic, values 'good enough' speed over perfection.
in_their_voice: The faster I get the themes, the faster we can iterate on the product.

name: Ryan Patel
life_stage: Teaching startups how to do customer interviews correctly.
relevant_history: Strong proponent of 'Continuous Discovery'; needs tools that support that pace.
emotional_baseline: Optimistic, early adopter of AI tools.
in_their_voice: I tell my clients: don't let transcription be the bottleneck of your discovery process.

name: Jessica Low
life_stage: Seasoned researcher at a large agency; managing complex multi-stakeholder studies.
relevant_history: Expert in thematic analysis; skeptical of AI being 'too generic' with its summaries.
in_their_voice: If the AI just gives me 'top 3 themes', it's useless; I need the evidence behind them.

name: Kevin Lee
life_stage: Veteran researcher known for high-quality ethnographic studies.
relevant_history: Has used every tool from Atlas.ti to Dovetail; still finds the 'synthesis gap' frustrating.
emotional_baseline: Patient, looking for a tool that 'thinks' like a researcher.
in_their_voice: Synthesis is where the magic happens, but right now it's where the most time is wasted.

name: Amanda White
life_stage: Managing a department; needs to standardize reporting across teams.
relevant_history: Frustrated by the variability in how different researchers analyze the same data.
emotional_baseline: Organized, focused on consistency and scale.
in_their_voice: I need a tool that creates a 'single source of truth' for our qualitative findings.

name: Michelle Davis
life_stage: Specializes in deep-dive consumer research; often works in the field.
relevant_history: Heavy user of mobile recording tools; needs a seamless way to ingest and analyze on the go.
in_their_voice: AI can help with the bulk, but it can't replace the hours I spend in the field observing.

name: George Brown
life_stage: Leading a practice focused on complex enterprise sales discovery.
relevant_history: Strong background in sales engineering; sees research as a data problem.
emotional_baseline: Pragmatic, looking for quantifiable qualitative insights.
in_their_voice: Show me the pain points that actually move the needle on sales.

name: Brian Miller
life_stage: Running a 50-person agency; constant pressure to improve margins.
relevant_history: Sees AI as the only way to stay competitive against low-cost 'automated' competitors.
emotional_baseline: Business-focused, slightly anxious about industry disruption.
in_their_voice: We need to automate the mundane so my researchers can focus on the high-value strategy.

name: Angela Scott
life_stage: Expert analyst who has seen the transition from cassette tapes to AI.
relevant_history: Loves the speed of AI but hates the loss of 'feel' for the data.
in_their_voice: I'll use AI to get the first draft, but I'll always be the one to sign off on the final themes.

name: Laura Wilson
life_stage: Running a boutique agency; focused on high-touch client relationships.
relevant_history: Wants to spend more time with clients and less time with transcripts.
in_their_voice: Anything that saves me ten hours a week is worth its weight in gold.

name: Steven Harris
life_stage: Leading strategy for major global brands; needs rapid consumer insights.
relevant_history: Needs to synthesize data from thousands of interviews across the globe.
in_their_voice: We need to find the signal in the noise before the market shifts again.

name: Sophia Zhang
life_stage: Second-year PhD candidate at Columbia; starting dissertation research.
relevant_history: Uses R for some data collection but finds it difficult to manage; relies on ChatGPT for coding help.
emotional_baseline: Excited but overwhelmed by the complexity of mixed methods.
in_their_voice: I want to do network analysis on rare disease experts, but I'm constantly hitting API limits and breaking my R scripts.

name: TRK 2121
life_stage: Focusing on medicalization and pharmaceutical innovation in China.
relevant_history: Purely qualitative background; experimenting with computational methods and AI agents.
emotional_baseline: Highly motivated (7/8 intensity) on solving version control and data pipeline issues.
in_their_voice: I'm experimenting with the computational way, but the biggest challenge is managing all those pipelines alone.

name: Marcus Thorne
life_stage: Third-year student; managing a large dataset of political speeches.
relevant_history: Uses Excel as an 'analog' for coding; aware of inter-rater reliability issues but lacks a system.
emotional_baseline: Frustrated by the manual 'grind' of qualitative analysis.
in_their_voice: I have thousands of documents and no confidence that my coding is consistent across them.

name: Emily Watson
life_stage: Writing up her ethnography; struggling with the volume of field notes.
relevant_history: Tried NVivo but found it didn't fit her 'immersive' style; manually tagging in Word.
emotional_baseline: Immersed but feeling the weight of the data.
in_their_voice: I need to keep the nuance of my field notes without getting lost in the thousands of pages.

name: Isabella Rossi
life_stage: Managing a team of research assistants; version control is a nightmare.
relevant_history: Uses Google Sheets for coding; constant issues with people overwriting each other's work.
in_their_voice: I'm terrified we're going to lose a month of coding because of a version control error.

name: David Kim
life_stage: Developing a new curriculum; interviewing dozens of teachers.
relevant_history: Using AI for initial summaries but needs a more rigorous way to track changes over time.
in_their_voice: I want to see how teacher feedback evolves across different versions of my curriculum.

name: Anna Belova
life_stage: Conducting interviews with healthcare providers in rural areas.
relevant_history: Needs to handle PII securely; currently using an on-premise transcription server that is very slow.
in_their_voice: Compliance is slowing my research down to a crawl; I need a secure but fast solution.

name: Daniel Smith
life_stage: Analyzing historical market data alongside contemporary interviews.
relevant_history: Heavy R user; wants to integrate qualitative themes into his quantitative models.
emotional_baseline: Analytical, looking for the 'bridge' between methods.
in_their_voice: Qualitative data shouldn't be a silo; I want to code it in a way that my R scripts can actually use.

name: Julia Martinez
life_stage: Studying social media trends; managing a massive archive of digital content.
relevant_history: Uses Python for scraping but finds the analysis part overwhelming.
in_their_voice: I can collect the data, but I can't synthesize it fast enough to keep up with the trends.

name: Grace O'Malley
life_stage: Working on a book project; synthesizing decades of archival research.
relevant_history: Strong believer in 'immersion'; skeptical of AI 'missing the context' of historical documents.
emotional_baseline: Thoughtful, protective of her research process.
in_their_voice: AI is a tool, but it lacks the historical 'nose' that a human researcher develops over years.

name: Thomas Brown
life_stage: Working professional doing a PhD; very limited time.
relevant_history: Needs maximum efficiency; currently pays a transcriptionist but finds the quality inconsistent.
in_their_voice: I only have 5 hours a week for my research; I can't spend 4 of them transcribing.

name: Rachel Adams
life_stage: Managing a large qualitative study on patient outcomes.
relevant_history: Expert in phenomenology; deeply skeptical of any tool that 'automates' understanding.
emotional_baseline: Serious, values the sanctity of the patient voice.
in_their_voice: Every patient's story is unique; you can't just 'extract themes' without losing the person.

name: Andrew White
life_stage: Studying community reactions to urban development.
relevant_history: Uses GIS and qualitative interviews; struggling to integrate the two.
in_their_voice: I need to map these themes to specific neighborhoods to see the real impact.

name: Simon Lee
occupation: Professor of Sociology (Transitioning to mixed methods)
life_stage: Senior academic trying to stay relevant in the age of big data.
relevant_history: Decades of purely qualitative work; feeling the 'peer pressure' to use AI/computational methods.
emotional_baseline: A bit anxious, feeling like he's 'lying behind'.
in_their_voice: The field is moving fast; if I don't learn how to use these tools, I'll be obsolete.

name: Catherine Gray
life_stage: Overseeing dozens of clinical research projects; focus on data quality.
relevant_history: Struggles with the gap between 'raw data' and 'publication-ready' results.
in_their_voice: I need to see the audit trail of how we got from the interview to the final theme.

name: Margeret Vance
life_stage: 20+ years of fieldwork; believes in 'thick description'.
relevant_history: Has seen many 'AI for research' tools fail to capture the subtext of human interaction.
emotional_baseline: Patient, deeply committed to the craft of research.
in_their_voice: AI can't feel the tension in the room during a difficult interview; it only hears the words.

name: Alice Morgan
occupation: Director of Qualitative Research, Large Agency
life_stage: Managing a team of 15 researchers; responsible for quality control.
relevant_history: Wary of 'hallucinations' in AI-generated summaries; insists on researchers reading every transcript.
emotional_baseline: Protective of her department's reputation for rigor.
in_their_voice: If my researchers stop reading the data, they stop being researchers; I won't let a tool dumb us down.

name: Robert Miller
life_stage: Left academia to consult; values intellectual independence.
relevant_history: Experienced in Grounded Theory; believes themes must 'emerge' naturally from the data, not be 'extracted'.
in_their_voice: The 'emergent' nature of research is what makes it valuable; AI-driven analysis feels too deterministic.

name: Paul Stevens
life_stage: Managing long-term strategy for tech giants; focus on deep user needs.
relevant_history: Has used AI for 'quantifying' qualitative data, but finds it misses the 'why' behind the 'what'.
in_their_voice: AI is great for counting keywords, but it's terrible at understanding human motivation.

name: Helen Wu
life_stage: Leading insights for a global FMCG company.
relevant_history: Seen 'AI' tools deliver generic insights that didn't help the business move forward.
in_their_voice: I've been burned by 'AI' that just summarizes what I already knew; show me something truly new.

name: Diane Clark
life_stage: Focus on social issues and policy; high-stakes research.
relevant_history: Deals with sensitive populations; fears AI might 'flatten' the diverse voices of her participants.
in_their_voice: When you automate analysis, you risk losing the very voices you're trying to represent.

name: William Scott
life_stage: Expert in cultural studies; values long-term immersion.
relevant_history: Spends months in the field; finds the idea of 'rapid' AI synthesis antithetical to good research.
emotional_baseline: Principled, values the slow work of understanding.
in_their_voice: Good research takes time; you can't shortcut the process of human understanding.

name: Karen Wilson
life_stage: Independent scholar working on health equity projects.
relevant_history: Needs to ensure AI doesn't introduce bias into the analysis of underserved communities.
in_their_voice: I'm worried about the algorithmic bias in AI analysis; who built these models and what do they know about my participants?

name: Susan Miller
life_stage: Overseeing complex medical studies; high regulatory burden.
relevant_history: Used AI for data entry but remains skeptical of its 'interpretive' capabilities.
in_their_voice: In clinical research, a small misinterpretation of a patient's response can have massive consequences.

name: Richard Davis
life_stage: Advising CEOs on culture and change; values the 'unspoken' data.
relevant_history: Expert in narrative inquiry; believes the 'story' is more than just the sum of its parts.
in_their_voice: AI can analyze the text, but it can't analyze the subtext of organizational politics.

name: Mary Hall
life_stage: Mentoring the next generation of researchers; focus on methodology.
relevant_history: Taught qualitative methods for 30 years; seen every 'short-cut' fail.
in_their_voice: I've seen many tools come and go; the only thing that remains is the need for rigorous, human-led analysis.

name: Edward Brown
life_stage: Managing policy research for a major think tank.
relevant_history: Needs absolute certainty in his findings; AI-generated 'insights' feel too flimsy for policy-making.
in_their_voice: If I can't defend the analysis process to a congressional committee, I won't use the tool.

name: Barbara Thompson
occupation: Director of Field Operations, Research Firm
life_stage: Managing hundreds of field researchers; focus on data quality.
relevant_history: Worried about the loss of 'researcher skill' as tools become more automated.
in_their_voice: If we outsource the thinking to AI, we lose the very thing our clients pay us for: our expertise.

name: Thomas Wright
life_stage: Expert in accessibility research; values the specific needs of individuals.
relevant_history: Finds that AI often misses the nuances of accessibility challenges.
in_their_voice: Accessibility is all about the edge cases; AI is built for the averages.

name: John Miller
life_stage: The 'old guard' of qualitative research; values the traditions of the field.
relevant_history: Built his agency on the reputation of deep, manual, high-quality analysis.
in_their_voice: You can't automate the human heart; that's where the real research happens.
